title: German Beef Rouladen Recipe
description: Flavorsome beef rouladen are pan-fried, then simmered in beef broth and served with a rich sour cream gravy in this traditional German recipe.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European German German Beef Rouladen 4.3 (151) 129 Reviews 17 Photos This beef rouladen recipe is another great German dish that reminds me of my mom's wonderful cooking. Enjoy this unique and delicious dish! Submitted by DebbyO Updated on October 6, 2023 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 17 17 17 17 Prep Time: 20 mins Cook Time: 35 mins Total Time: 55 mins Servings: 8 Yield: 8 rouladen Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings ¼ cup Dijon mustard 8 (4 ounce) pieces round steak, pounded 1/4 inch thick ½ cup minced onion 2 teaspoons paprika 2 teaspoons salt 2 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper 8 slices bacon 3 tablespoons canola oil 1 (12 ounce) can beef broth 1 ¼ cups water 2 tablespoons cornstarch 1 cup warm water ¼ cup sour cream Directions Spread 1/2 tablespoon mustard over one side of each piece of steak; sprinkle onion, paprika, salt, and pepper evenly over the steaks. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Lay one slice of bacon on each piece; roll up steaks jelly roll-style and secure with toothpicks. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat canola oil in a skillet over medium heat; cook beef rouladen on all sides until browned. Add broth and water; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low; cover and simmer until tender, about 30 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Remove beef rouladen; strain broth mixture and return liquid to the skillet. Whisk cornstarch and 1 cup of water together until smooth; slowly pour cornstarch mixture into the skillet, stirring continually until the sauce has thickened, 2 to 3 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stir in sour cream; return rolls to the sauce and serve immediately. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 233 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 351 Calories 16g Fat 5g Carbs 45g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 8 Calories 351 % Daily Value * Total Fat 16g 20% Saturated Fat 5g 23% Cholesterol 113mg 38% Sodium 1133mg 49% Total Carbohydrate 5g 2% Dietary Fiber 1g 2% Total Sugars 1g Protein 45g 89% Vitamin C 1mg 2% Calcium 24mg 2% Iron 4mg 24% Potassium 489mg 10% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of German Beef Rouladen 01 of 17 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 17 Photo by  SDCrawford 01/21/2020 03 of 17 Photo by  lutzflcat 01/27/2019 1.27.19 I didn’t have any sour cream on hand for the gravy, so I omitted it. Recipe doesn’t call for much anyway, so I didn’t ’t think it would be a game changer. Since I was looking for a rich beef gravy, I used all beef stock, no water. I had a few mushrooms in the fridge, so I sautéed them, and added after the gravy had thickened. I checked the rolls after 30 minutes, and they were not nearly tender enough (this is round steak, after all), so I ended up cooking for 1-1/4 hours at which time they were good-to-go. I added a little browning sauce (Kitchen Bouquet®) to get a richer, darker gravy for better eye appeal. That dijon mustard gave the beef rolls just a bit of tang, and the gravy was rich and robust, with just a hint of bacon. Served today with Red Cabbage (recipe on this site), sautéed fresh egg noodles, and freshly-cooked apples. My husband’s family has German roots, he is accustomed to German cuisine, and he gave this a thumbs up! 04 of 17 Photo by  Gadge Teman 06/30/2017 This was a fabulous dish. I made my version of Spetzel with it and my girlfriend made German potato salad. I loved it. 05 of 17 Photo by  Ladypearl 09/18/2016 06 of 17 Photo by  Patty Swinehart 08/21/2016 07 of 17 Photo by  Sandra Dale 03/22/2016 So I made this tonight and my husband a daughter and myself loved it. (I did forget to add the onion and paprika)There was a bit to much pickle for my husband so he took one of the wedges out. My one son didn't like the bacon (he normally doesn't like bacon) but said it was okay minus the bacon. My youngest son loved it also. Next time I won't add as much pickle and maybe less bacon. 08 of 17 Photo by  seasha 10/13/2015 09 of 17 Photo by  naples34102 04/30/2015 Authentic, traditional or not, I don’t care. What matters to me is if it tastes good. I’ve made “Roll Mops” for years, but never with Dijon or sour cream and both seemed interesting ingredients to try. From the start, however, I knew I would use all broth, no water, to ensure a rich gravy. Also, 30 minutes is not nearly long enough to cook round steak to tenderness. It must be braised for more like an hour and a half. While Hubs and I both enjoyed this (because of a gravy prepared with all broth), we both agree it’s better without the Dijon and without the sour cream. Perhaps we’re just stuck in our ways. 10 of 17 Photo by  Neal Shawn 02/06/2012 1 2 Next You’ll Also Love Grillhaxe (Grilled Eisbein, Pork Shanks) 10 Ratings German Rouladen 352 Ratings Big Ben's Beef Machaca 47 Ratings Filet Mignon with Bacon Cream Sauce 105 Ratings Asian Beef with Snow Peas 1,346 Ratings Feta-Stuffed Hamburgers 85 Ratings Authentic Bangladeshi Beef Curry 91 Ratings Filet Mignon with Mushroom-Cabernet Gravy 117 Ratings Grilled Balsamic and Soy Marinated Flank Steak 114 Ratings Nana Lara's Brisket 20 Ratings Juicy Marinated Steaks 154 Ratings Gourmet Grilling Burgers 17 Ratings Crab-Stuffed Filet Mignon with Whiskey Peppercorn Sauce 316 Ratings Grilled Mexican Steak 33 Ratings Filet Mignons with Pepper Cream Sauce 151 Ratings Mediterranean Stuffed Swordfish 72 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. Reduce heat to medium-low; cover and simmer until tender, about 30 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Remove beef rouladen; strain broth mixture and return liquid to the skillet.
